dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside and around the buildings, the rest of the NDF Battalion rests and waits for orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two-I-C wheezes. Agu sits at one of the desks separating bullet from its shell, empties the gun powder onto a piec gum foil. Agu lights the powder in a POOF. He scrapes the white-grey residue into a line and sniffs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon is full and shines into the room. Finally, Two-I stops moaning. Agu turns and looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Approaching Two-I-C, thinking he is dead. Two-I-C's eyes open and he's trying to whisper something. Agu cannot hea it. He leans in closer. Two-I-C's breaths a death rattle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are just a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu looks at his hand, clammy and yellow, fingers grippin his blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know you are just a boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two-I-C begins to tremble, panic. Agu reaches for his han holds it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was this all for nothing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Two-I-C, unsure why he is feeling sad for thi man at this moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is like God is turning his gaze on Two-I-C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two-I-C exhales, the trembling ceases. He is dead. Agu, d by the fading light, walks to the balcony overlooking the town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu? Is that you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu can barely perceive Commandant sitting in the railing his skin reflecting the faint embers of a joint cupped in hands. Agu does not respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu. Come. Sit down with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu leans into the railing. Commandant rubs the back of h neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is dangerous times now, Agu. Can't be trusting nobody. That is why it is always good to be sleeping with one eye open. And that is why I have you and Strika.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tripod enters with RADIO OPERATOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodblood is asking for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commandant waves him away. Tripod, aware things have chan waits an explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes Agu, sometimes I am feeling sorry for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu cannot tell if he heard him say it or if he dreamed h said it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two-I-C is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preacher SINGS over Two-I-C's body. They strip him of his "Two-I-C" jacket, his belt, boots, and anything else of u He is left with only his dirty socks and underwear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is taking Two-I-C all day to be dying, and then he is dying when the moon is full and the night is shining like silver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are my new Two-I-C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commandant places the jacket on Tripod, who proudly puts on over his bare chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The the only way not to be fighting anymore is to be dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was not God's work. This was man's. The Supreme Commander was our friend. Now he is our enemy. But we are not fearing change... for we are strong!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strong and proud!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is why we should be taking our own territory and filling our own pockets. Move out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The NDF Soldiers take stock in what they have, burn their vehicles and move out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fog swirls along the canopy of the jungle. Commandant's t has been reduced to a small lean to, separate from where everyone else sleeps under the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother. If this war is ever ending I am thinking, I cannot be going back to doing child thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone sleeps. Suddenly they are attacked from unseen forces. Bullets pound the ground around them, burying men dirt and tearing others up with shrapnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are just wild animals now with no place to be going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu and Strika hold each other while bullet shells pour o them. The battle is over as quickly as it began.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commandant is frazzled. He picks up his hat, dusting it o while yelling for the men to fall back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preacher moves up and down the line, checking the men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tripod, Hope!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu looks down the line. They are both bleeding. Hope is dead. Tripod still breathes, but his body is leaking bloo from many wounds. He screams while staring wildly at ever looking down at him, breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes roll into the back of his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullet is just eating everything, leaf, tree, ground, person -- eating them -- just making person to bleed everywhere... so much blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pick through the useful gear and begin to move out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preacher whispers a prayer to himself as Commandant pulls Tripod's Two-I-C jacket off and places it on Preacher, unceremoniously as the men move out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu collapses with Strika at their next bivouac. The men nothing, they are all too exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUN FIRE ECHOES in the distance. Everyone is silent looki at Commandant for guidance, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commandant signals, move down the line..."move out."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu puts his pack on and starts to leave when he sees Str is immovable, lizard licking his chapped lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strika? Strika! We are having to go or they will be leaving us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strika shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu watches as the others disappear into the bush without them. He turns back to Strika.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strika! We have to be going. Stand up and let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strika shakes his head, sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu goes to Strika.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strika looks at Agu, wheezing. He shows Agu a small shrap wound in his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worried but with no other choice, Agu picks Strika up and throws him onto his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu notices a cricket on a leaf. He snatches it quickly, bites half of it, then gives the other half to Strika, wh lets it sit in his mouth with out swallowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am wanting to say to Strika, I am tired too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUN FIRE ECHOES again in the distance. Quietly, they move again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am tired, and so the words are not coming out of my mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu picks up Strika to carry him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will be an old man before this war is over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu hears it and sits up quickly. It's the song his mothe used to sing to him in the kitchen hut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enh... Strika, a song. Music. Like my mother sings...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around, trying to find its ephemeral source. But goes silent. He tries to see if Strika is listening, his resting on Agu's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strika?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes Strika. But Strika doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strika?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Realizing he is dead, Agu lays him down and cries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu covers Strika with leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commandant looks at him, pitifully. Then leads the men on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu stands alone in knee deep water peeing into the same. notices a floating corpse next to where he is peeing, its BOOTS looking in decent condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops peeing and pries the boots off, falling back int the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he gets up he notices the GIRL from the whorehouse, fully pregnant trying to climb out of the trench to escap

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His first instinct is to grab his rifle and aim. She sees this, they lock eyes, but she tests him, stepping higher. lowers his aim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She thanks him with her eyes, but doesn't make it more th 15 feet before SWOOFFF, a bullet from a SNIPER far off on other side of a BURNED FIELD drops her - the MEN the tren Agu is hiding in was built to hide from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu, only briefly saddened by the quick end to the girl, back to prying off the dead man's boot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain mists on Agu, newish boots hanging on his should from their laces. The MOTHER'S SONG sings again from some place off in the mist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, your song is making my body to move and I am not having to think anymore, not about Strika, not about this war, not about any of the thing that are jumping into my head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits in a fox hole overlooking the burnt field. PREACH tries to take a pop shot at someone on the other side of field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ammo. Find me some fucking bullets to be shooting, Agu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu points to the man he pried the boots from. Bored, he to find ammo, digging through abandoned rifles and dead bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be going to that person who is singing and taking all of the sound so I can be keeping it in my pocket, to be having it for myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trench is filled with more water. Agu walks through i towards the inner part of the NDF defenses, the water up his belly so he rests his rifle on his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am wanting to lie down on the warm ground with my eye closed and the smell of mud in my nose, just like Strika.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu looks at his reflection in the water staring back at He moves, it moves. He walks, it follows. Around him, the have created smaller mini-indentations to protect themsel from the rain of shrapnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am wanting to feel how the ground is wet all around my body so that if I am sweating, I am feeling like it is the ground sweating through me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NDF Soldiers are like ghosts in the heavy mist. He cannot more than a couple feet in front of him at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I am wanting to stay in this same place forever, never moving for anything, just waiting waiting until dust is piling on me and grasses is covering me and insect is making their home in the space between my teeths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rounds an intersection in the trench with a wooden def protecting it from exposure, leading deeper into the wood

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One onina tree will be growing from my body, so wide that its trunk is separating night and day and so tall that its top leaf is tickling the moon until the man living there is smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu enters the gold mining area of their encampment. He s to put on his new boots while looking at the lackluster industry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commandant sits on a throne of earth, a purple rappa cove him from the rain like a tribal king. He stares at the sk joint hanging gingerly in his dirty fingers, ash floating the water all around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commandant, suh. We are out of bullets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kai! This fog, Agu. It is our friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu nods, dutifully. Commandant relights the joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He motions for Agu to come over to him. Agu does, slowly, trudging through the shallower water. Commandant puts his on him, gently caressing his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was not supposed to be the way it has come to be, Agu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu doesn't seem to know how to answer the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone betrays you, eventually. But, I will always look out for you, Agu. I will look out for you because you are my son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the mist, Agu hears voices, restless voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a son always protects his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu pulls away from Commandant and trudges towards the entrance to let Preacher through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preacher emerges from the whiteness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am needing to be speaking with you Commandant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is all this noise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commandant shouts from his thrown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are leaving, sah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who and who is leaving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preacher pushes Agu aside, knocking him against the wall the trench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is leaving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preacher blinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two-I-C, go back to your post.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Sah. We are going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are the only one stupid standing in front of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am going, sah! I have no bullets, I cannot be shooting our enemy with no bullets. There is no gold, no money, nothing to be buying more bullets. So I am going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am going too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More voices call out from beyond the mist that they are leaving, farther and farther into the trenches, until the smallest voices are still yelling "me too!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commandant's eyes grow dark. Preacher subtly slides his h down his rifle, still hanging on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Electricity courses through Agu's temples, fear and confu cloud his face. More men move to support Preacher, and Ag sees this, knowing his bullets couldn't stop them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. I see you are a big man now, Two-I-C. And where will you be going? You will surrender to the other NDF? No. They will eat you. And to the ECOMOD? That would be wiser, but, then what? Jail? War crimes? If they let you go, you think you will ever have it as good as you have it right now in this mud? You think that you will be able to just do what you want in "peace"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He paces along the trench, leaning into his men, centimet away from their noses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all will go back to your towns, but they will fear you. Your families will not associate with you. You will be nobodies, with your poor, uneducated minds. And you will sit all day, and you will watch the sun rise and set, waiting with thousands of others for some big man to come along and say "I have some job for you."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around, gauging the comprehension of his men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orphans. You are all orphans like me. You think I will let you waste what little time you have left on this earth drinking black tea and playing draughts with your gun powder tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commandant turns, looks at Agu, gripping his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks straight towards Agu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs the rifle, kneels down, holding it against his h and closing his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to kill me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu can't. Commandant is disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to surrender?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then surrender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to the rest of the men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you are poor and hungry with nothing to do with your nothing days, you will remember these days as your best. And know, one day I will call on you again. And you will come. Because you will remember this, and you will come running. Nobody has it better than us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preacher climbs out of the trench. The others move to fol Commandant turns to Agu, his rifle still raised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu, in a column with the rest of the NDF Soldiers walks their arms and weapons raised flat in the air. The sun sh hot over their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun, why are you even thinking to shine on this world. I am wanting to catch you in my hand, to be squeezing until the color is dripping out from you forever. That way everywhere it is always dark and nobody is ever having to see any of the terrible thing that is happening in this world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance, waiting UN forces guide them through the defensive position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they pass a line of former ECOMOD TROOPS now re-organi as UN forces, Agu notices the 2nd Lieutenant from his hom village, Alpha Town, the man he sold his imagination TV t but the man does not recognize Agu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Agu stares at him, the 2nd Lieutenant is forced to mak eye contact with him, but can't make out why this young fighter is staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In heaven, it is always morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ceiling fan spins around in circles. Agu stares at it w laying in a clean bed of white sheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is healthy. His skin fresh, his face filled in. His ey clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside, children scream -- with joy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu sits up. Child-like drawings of war flutter on a desk under the ventilation of the fan. He steps out of bed and stares out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Permanent wooden blinds split his view horizontally, but can see through them, at DOZENS of children running into turquoise waters of the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not knowing how long I am staying here, but I am staying here for a long time -- some week, some month -- I am not knowing. All I am knowing is how it is feeling here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu stares at the other children at play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He notices a miniature crab running sideways in the sand, making a tiny trail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks back at the kids playing by the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young WOMAN, AMY (20s) watches Agu. He doesn't join the other children, he stays separate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I am eating even if I am not hungrying too much because I am fearing that the food is finishing for the next day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu dresses in new clothes, stares into a mirror at himse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am liking the clothes is clean and dry and it is not having any hole from bullet or blood from the last person who is wearing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children scream as FATHER FRIDAY, (50s) enters the compound in a Land Rover. They swarm him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Friday sits in front of Agu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn to God. Confession and Forgiveness and Resurrection, these are the things you need to know to bring the life back to your life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He continues while Agu listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not knowing all what he is meaning. The only thing that is making sense to me is memory that I am having of another boy -- Strika - - sleeping next to me, so close because we are the only people protecting each other from all of the thing trying to kill us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu and Strika holding on to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu sits defensively in front of the Father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only thing I am knowing is the sound of people coughing and screaming, and the smell of going to toilet and dead body. And the feeling of the brown brown and djamba in my blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same dorm room, several weeks earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu sweats in bed, his body aching as the drugs and poiso leave his system. He shakes in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids, including Agu, raid the kitchen threatening the COOKS, they lock them inside the kitchen and take over th school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CHILDREN -- months earlier when they first got to the shelter, are angry, confused, drugs still coursing throug their nervous systems -- burn items of furniture, beds, t legs, and throw them into the courtyard as the WORKERS tr calm them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu, though we cannot hear it, throws his fist in the air chanting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Friday calms the children down, his hands outstret waiting for them to give him the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confession and Forgiveness and resurrection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Friday unlocks the doors. The children, including apologize to the staff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Above all, my boy. Have faith in God and trust in him because he is the one helping you to understand what these words mean. Do you have a Bible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu sits with several of the SBU boys. Preacher, and who else is still alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are not even paying us an allowance. How are we supposed to be living on this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go Preacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Friday pulls out a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I am having Bible, but I am using to be holding my drawing down on my desk so the fan is not throwing them everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu and Preacher hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are saying they are needing soldier, fighting is what I am knowing and that is what I should be doing. You are sure you do not want to fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu nods. Preach and TWO other NDF ADOLESCENTS jump the f and sneak off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy sits in front of Agu. She is quiet, making an effort show she cares what he is saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy. She is always looking at me like looking at me is going to be helping me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, try, try to talk about it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She thinks that my not speaking is because I can't be explaining myself like baby... but I am not like baby, I am like old man and she is like small girl because I am fighting in war and she is not even knowing what war is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what you are feeling, or, try to tell me what you are thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am thinking about my future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, yes, good. And how do you see your future?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs. A fan buzzes overhead. He looks at it, subtly THUMPING like a helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Botu botu botu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to talk about some of your experiences?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. But it might make you feel better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agu stares at her for a long moment. So unbroken that Amy to look away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am seeing more terrible thing than ten thousand men and I am doing more terrible thing than twenty thousand men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy looks at him sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, if I am saying these thing that I do, then it will be making me to sadding too much and you too sadding to much in this life. I am wanting to be happy in this life because of everything I am seeing. I am just wanting to be happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy's eyes water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I am telling this to you it will be making you to think that I am some sort of beast or devil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am all of this thing. I am all of this thing, but I am also having mother and father and brother and sister once, and they were loving me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of children run into the water, screaming, writhin passing around a ball in large circles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a distance, Agu watches them play, a part of him yearning to join them, a part of him feeling like that version of himself is long gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, surprising even to him, he cannot help but step forw at first walking, then running out towards the water, splashing into the frothy waves to join them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We last glimpse him as he dives underwater.
